Nutrition Sleuth

The truth about food fads, supplements, and diet scams
Posted in: Diet & Nutrition

Does a High Alkaline Diet Really Boost Your Health?

By Johannah Sakimura, RD

Interest in high alkaline diets is peaking, thanks to recent endorsements from high-profile celebs like Kelly Ripa. Though websites and books claim that following an “acid-reducing” eating pattern improves well-being, strengthens bones, fights cancer and other diseases, boosts energy, and relieves pain, scientific support is lacking.

Like many specialized diets, the alkaline diet is based on a scientific theory that sounds logical enough. The diet divides foods into two categories: acid-producing foods and alkaline-producing foods. Acid-producing foods, including animal proteins, dairy, and grains, break down into compounds that promote a lower (more acidic) pH, which purportedly stresses the body and promotes disease. Alkaline-producing foods, primarily vegetables and fruits, contain minerals like potassium, magnesium, and calcium that neutralize acids and raise pH, creating an internal environment that’s more beneficial to health.

However, the acidity of the foods we eat has little effect on our body’s pH level. For reference, a pH of 7 is neutral, and a pH less than 7 falls in the acid range. The body has multiple systems in place that tightly regulate blood pH and maintain it within a window of 7.35 to 7.45, but ideally right at 7.4, which is slightly alkaline. When our blood pH begins to deviate from baseline, our lungs respond by increasing or decreasing our breathing rate to bring the body back into balance. Our kidneys also help to reestablish an optimal pH by adjusting the acidity of our urine. While our urine pH will decrease after eating an acid-promoting meal, our body staunchly defends its internal acid-base set point.

Alkaline Diet and Bone Health

Though blood pH isn’t significantly altered by diet, alkaline diet proponents argue that eating a high-acid load causes downstream problems over the long term. One common claim is that a high-protein, acid-producing diet weakens bones because heavy protein intake has been found to increase calcium losses in the urine. Some researchers hypothesized that the body may release calcium from bone to help buffer the acids from food, thus sacrificing bone tissue to maintain a safe pH.

However, this theory has not been upheld by recent research. Carefully controlled studies have shown that a high-protein diet also increases calcium absorption from food, which appears to offset the increased losses in urine. The balance of evidence shows that people who eat higher-protein diets have greater bone density and strength, although the effect on fracture risk is still uncertain. There’s no need to go overboard on protein from poultry, fish, dairy, and other animal sources, but restricting these foods doesn’t appear to be beneficial for skeletal health, and falling short on total protein intake can be harmful.

Alkaline Diet and Cancer

Another popular claim is that following an alkaline diet protects against cancer and makes cancer treatments more successful. While cancer cells grow better in acidic environments in laboratory studies, eating a high-acid diet does not shift the body’s pH; it only alters urine pH. Furthermore, there is no evidence from studies conducted in people to suggest that following an alkaline diet reduces cancer risk or improves the chances of remission.

The Upside of the Alkaline Diet

Generally speaking, an alkaline diet promotes a healthy eating pattern by encouraging you to eat ample produce and emphasizing plant-based proteins. However, research does not support the idea that strictly following an alkaline diet promotes bone health or prevents other ailments. Vegetables and fruits, along with vegetarian proteins like beans and nuts, are rich sources of the minerals and vitamins that keep bones strong and sturdy and protect against a whole host of conditions, so it is certainly beneficial to eat more of these foods. Rather than micromanaging acid-base levels, I advise people to look at the bigger picture and focus on eating a wide variety of minimally-processed, plant-based foods.

What About Alkaline Water?

While we’re on the topic, there’s really no reason to drink those special alkaline waters that are now catching on. If you plan to buy them anyway, I suggest choosing brands that owe their alkalinity to their mineral content, as opposed to ionized waters that are treated to alter the pH. Mineral waters supply small amounts of calcium and magnesium, nutrients that tend to be lacking in our diet and offer many health benefits irrespective of their alkaline nature. But keep in mind that the mineral content is minimal compared to what you can get from the top food sources, so there’s really no reason to spend the extra money. Plain old tap water is better than fine.
